body:
After using Samsung Galaxy S2 for about two years, I was convinced that all android apps have this nice, subtle, noise texture on all gradient UI elements.

Here is a picture of android keyboard, a bad iPhone camera gives a bit more emphasis on the gradients granularity.

It was surprising and a bit unnerving to see the same apps on Nexus 5. All those smooth, gliding gradients kept bringing up memories like upgrading a video card on an old 486 box and running Windows 95 with 16 bit color for the first time.

Super Amoled display works by having each pixel represented by three light emitting sub-pixels (Red, Green, Blue). Those sub-pixels have more limited lifespan than a typical light source of traditional back-lit screens. The balance between their lifespan and intensity is very delicate, apparently making it very hard to display a consistent gradient.

Ignoring the difference in resolution, the grainy gradient is still pretty visible on Galaxy S2 (left) vs Nexus 5 (right).

Nexus 5 comes with IPS screen and although I miss S2's black colors (when pixel is completely off and no light is emitted at all), the smooth gradients, higher resolution and just over all a healthy looking screen of Nexus 5 is an amazing upgrade.
